## **Previously on 201**
### Movement test
<br>
- If you can move a string of words **together to another place** in a sentence while meaning about the same thing, the string is a constituent. <br><br>
  - **Clefting**: putting the string of words between <b><span style="color:orange">it was</span></b>/<b><span style="color:orange">it is</span></b> and a <b><span style="color:orange">that</span></b>/<b><span style="color:orange">who</span></b>/<b><span style="color:orange">who</span></b> at the beginning of the sentence<br><br>
  - **Preposing**:  putting the string of words before a <b><span style="color:orange">is</span></b>/<b><span style="color:orange">are</span></b> <b><span style="color:orange">what</span></b> or <b><span style="color:orange">is</span></b>/<b><span style="color:orange">are</span></b> <b><span style="color:orange">who</span></b> at the beginning of the sentence<br><br>

.pull-left[
- She bought <b><u><span style="color:green">a brand new car</span></u></b>.<br><br>
  - **Clefting**: <b><span style="color:orange">It was</span></b> <b><u><span style="color:green">a brand new car</span></u></b> that she bought.
  - **Preposing**: <b><u><span style="color:green">A brand new car</span></u></b> <b><span style="color:orange">was what</span></b> she bought.
]
.pull-left[
- She <b><u><span style="color:green">bought a brand</span></u></b> new car.<br><br>
  - **Clefting**: **\* **<b><span style="color:orange">It was</span></b> <b><u><span style="color:green">bought a brand</span></u></b> that she (did) new car...
  - **Preposing**: **\* **<b><u><span style="color:green">Bought a brand</span></u></b> <b><span style="color:orange">was what</span></b> she (did) new car...
]

## **Previously on 201**
### Movement test
<br>
- If you can move a string of words **together to another place** in a sentence while meaning about the same thing, the string is a constituent. <br><br>
  - **Clefting**: putting the string of words between <b><span style="color:orange">it was</span></b>/<b><span style="color:orange">it is</span></b> and a <b><span style="color:orange">that</span></b>/<b><span style="color:orange">who</span></b>/<b><span style="color:orange">who</span></b> at the beginning of the sentence<br><br>
  - **Preposing**:  putting the string of words before a <b><span style="color:orange">is</span></b>/<b><span style="color:orange">are</span></b> <b><span style="color:orange">what</span></b> or <b><span style="color:orange">is</span></b>/<b><span style="color:orange">are</span></b> <b><span style="color:orange">who</span></b> at the beginning of the sentence<br><br>

.pull-left[
- They played <b><u><span style="color:green">in the garden</span></u></b>.<br>
  - <b><u><span style="color:green">in the garden</span></u></b> is a constituent<br><br>

- They <b><u><span style="color:green"> played in the garden</span></u></b>.<br>
  - <b><u><span style="color:green">played in the garden</span></u></b> is a constituent

]
.pull-left[
- They <b><u><span style="color:green">studied for the exam</span></u></b> in the library.<br>
  - <b><u><span style="color:green">studied for the exam</span></u></b> is a constituent<br><br>

- They <b><u><span style="color:green">studied for</span></u></b> the exam in the library.<br>
  - <b><u><span style="color:green">studied for</span></u></b> is not a constituent
]

## **Previously on 201**
<br>
###**constituent**: a group of words that <span style="color:green"><b>acts together</b></span> as a **unit** <br><br>

### **phrases**: types of constituents
<br>
- Each phrase has a main word or **head**, and they are named after the **head** word's **part of speech** (PoS):<br><br>
  - **noun phrase** (<span style="color:green"><b>NP</b></span>): *<u>man</u>, the <u>man</u>, the happy <u>man</u>, the <u>man</u> with the hat*<br><br>
  - **prepositional phrase** (<span style="color:purple"><b>PP</b></span>): *<u>into</u> the forest, <u>by</u> the author, <u>for</u> good luck*<br><br>
  - **verb phrase** (<span style="color:blue"><b>VP</b></span>): *<u>eats</u>, <u>eats</u> pizza, <u>eats</u> quickly, <u>eats</u> pizza quickly at noon*<br><br>
  - **adjective phrase** (<span style="color:orange"><b>AdjP</b></span>): *<u>happy</u>, <u>ugly</u>*<br><br>
  - **adverb phrase** (<span style="color:brown"><b>AdvP</b></span>): *<u>quickly</u>, <u>happily</u>*
  
---
## **Phrase Structure Rules** (PSRs)
<br>
There are (descriptive) rules that indicate **how phrases are built out of smaller units** (which could be words or other phrases)<br><br>
  - These rules are called **phrase structure rules** <br><br>
  - They indicate the order and position of the smaller units in a phrase <br><br>

We derive these rules by observing what are the possible structures that exist in natural language<br><br>

## **Phrase Structure Rules for English**
<br>
.pull-left[
- <h3><b><span style="color:green">NP</span></b> → (D) (AdjP+) <b><span style="color:red">N</span></b> (PP+)</h3><br>
- <h3><b><span style="color:green">PP</span></b> → <b><span style="color:red">P</span></b> NP</h3><br>
- <h3><b><span style="color:green">AdjP</span></b> → (AdvP) <b><span style="color:red">Adj</span></b></h3><br>
- <h3><b><span style="color:green">AdvP</span></b> → (AdvP) <b><span style="color:red">Adv</span></b></h3><br>
]
.pull-right[
- <h3><b><span style="color:green">TP</span></b> → NP <b><span style="color:red">(T)</span></b> VP</h3><br>
- <h3><b><span style="color:green">CP</span></b> → <b><span style="color:red">C</span></b> TP</h3><br>
]
- <h3><b><span style="color:green">VP</span></b> → (AdvP+) <b><span style="color:red">V</span></b> (NP) (NP) (AdvP+) (PP+) (AdvP+)</h3>

## Quick Notes
<br>
**h. I throw a ball to the dog with a collar in the park.**
1. draw an AdjP for **each** adjective, an AdvP for **each** adverb <br><br>
2. if X modifies Y, X must be a child of the same parent as Y <br><br>
.pull-left[
<img src="../pic/1003/ndog.png" width="80%">
]
.pull-right[
<img src="../pic/1003/vdog.png" width="80%">
]
<br>
- So here on the **LEFT**, PP is under a NP, which means this PP modifies the **head N** (dog) in the NP (dog is in the park);and on the **RIGHT**, PP is under a VP, which means this PP modifies the **head V** (threw) in the VP (thowing happens in the park). This is where sometimes there is **AMBIGUITY**! It is because of PP can be under either an NP or a VP according to our **phrase structure rules**.

### **Tense Phrases (TP)**
<br>
**Sentences** are labeled as tense phrases. In many cases, we can split a sentence into a **NP** and a **VP**
<br><br>
.pull-left[
- <h3><b><span style="color:green">TP</span></b> → NP <b><span style="color:red">(T)</span></b> VP</h3>
<br>
The **head** of a TP is the **T(ense)** node<br><br>
It can be occupied by: <br><br>
  - overt **auxiliaries** (is, was, are, will, have...)<br><br>
  - **modals** (can, could...), or<br><br>
  - infinitive marker **to**<br><br>
  - abstract **present/past tense**]
.pull-right[
<img src="../pic/1003/t1.png" width="40%"><br><br>
'*Tina will escape.*'
<br><br>
<img src="../pic/1003/t2.png" width="40%"><br><br>
'*Tina escaped.*'
]

### **Complementiser Phrases (CP)**
<br>
.pull-left[
Consider the following sentence: <br><br>
  - Tina thinks <u>that her brother has finished his homework</u>.<br><br>
  
Is the underlined string a constituent?<br><br>
  - <u>That her brother has finished his homework</u> is what Tina thinks.
  - What does Tina think? <u>That her brother has finished his homework</u>.<br><br>
  
**CP**s are sentences preceded by a complementiser:<br>
- <h3><b><span style="color:green">CP</span></b> → <b><span style="color:red">C</span></b> TP</h3>]

**step 7**: check whether what we currently assume is working <br><br>

- **yet do we finish everything?** nope, we still have <b><u>aem</b></u> and <b><u>id</b></u> to figure out<br><br>

- it seems they are not **tense**-related, since in **a** and **e** (or **c** and **d**), <b><u>aem</b></u> (or <b><u>id</b></u>) can occur either in *present progressive tense* or in *past tense*<br><br>

But we find that <b><u>aem</b></u> only occurs together with <span style="color:red">maen</span>, and <b><u>id</b></u> only with <span style="color:purple">shoma</span>, so they are also **person**-related
